author: Skut
title: "Shuttle, this is Chase 1..."
review:
This is a great set.  Big trucks and fast planes are always popular with kids, and this set has both. 

Lego hasn't released many small jets in the City (or, for that matter, Town) lines over the years - fans have mostly had to make do with airliners or cargo aricraft.  Even the occasional smaller jets (for example the cargo plane in 6377 Cargo Center or the Police jet in 6344 Jet Speed Justice) have featured podded engines. 

This set provides a new development for Lego - a fighter-like craft with an internal jet engine whose role could be Shuttle pilot training (as the set name suggests), or a chase plane, or both.  The overall concept of the set evokes a T-38 as flown by NASA.  None of Lego's previous Spaceport subthemes (Town or City) has used this exact set concept before, so it's good to see Lego trying something new. 

So, that's the concept of the set.  Does it work in practice?  YES is the resounding answer. 

First, the plane - overall an impressive effort, with innovative use of parts particularly at the rear of the aircraft.  The folding wings are a necessity for road transportation of the jet and give a bit of an aircraft carrier feel, plus added playability.  The landing gear is, like all Lego City aircraft since 1985, fixed and therefore must be removed and stored separately if you want to swoosh the plane around in "wheels up" mode.  In looks the plane is pretty close to a Folland Gnat (the plane from Hot Shots!) except for the low wings. 

It's not perfect - the nose section feels unfinished and I can't for the life of me work out why a 2x2 plate was used in front of the canopy rather than a 2x2 tile.  The pilot also lacks a joystick which, given the tiny cost of adding a 1x1 aerial to the parts count, is a lapse.

The truck (semi trailer) is the good effort we have come to expect from TLG over recent years.  The prime mover looks appropriately powerful, and the trailer makes clever use of the low-slung railway chassis which goes way back to the days of 9V trains like the Metroliner.  The (relatively) recent move to 6 wide vehicles has given Lego good reason to employ this element on road vehicles and it's used to good effect here, and is well proportioned with the rest of the rig. 

Finally, the little "Follow Me" vehicle is a nice touch and definitely adds to play value. 

There is no obvious mechanism to roll the plane on of off the truck, so your spaceport will need some sort of crane to achieve this.  I doubt the truck could drive fast enough for the plane to be flown off (or landed on) the trailer, but then again in the world of kids' imaginations anything is possible. 

The minifigs (3) are a bit "meh" collectability-wise but are definitely appropriate to the set.  The astronaut/pilot is the only minifig in the Spaceport sets to come with a motorbike/pilot helmet (as opposed to an astronaut's EVA helmet), which does offer a tiny bit of uniqueness to this set. 

So, in conclusion, a very solid set in a solid subtheme (Spaceport) and sure to be a winner with the kids.
